review: It strikes the same chord as iPhone vs Android phones. The Apple TV may have less widgets and apps, but the user interface is far superior to the Fire TV. I find this product to have confusing controls, cluttered menu, and the navigation is a pain compared to the simplicity of an Apple product. The benefit is not having to aim the remote directly to the receiver, and a ton of networks to choose from. However, if given the choice between all the on-demand media boxes, I would go with Apple.
author: FXguy

review: Been using a Roku for a few years, but it died recently, and also happened to receive one of these Fire TV Sticks as a birthday gift.I expected a much better product - most of my Amazon experience has been very positive.So here's the comparison:1) Why would something meant to get power from the HDMI port still require being plugged into the wall? I've done so, but how much juice does this thing need?2) Whatever I happen to be streaming at any given moment on it randomly either freezes, or the screen freezes with the sound continuing. It happens often enough that I am planning on ditching this device and purchasing a new Roku, which never had that problem.3) If I want to watch something from Amazon that's not available for free, it doesn't give me the option of renting it, only buying it outright - so I have to go to another device (computer or mobile) and rent the movie using that medium instead. You'd think a device built by Amazon would function with as much fidelity as their website does - but it seems designed to get you to spend more money by not allowing some options.
